Headlam's career took off in the summer of 1937 when he was sent to the Far East to take part in the war against Japan. In August he was posted to No. 1 FTS, which was based at Rabaul, New Britain, and in September he was promoted to flight lieutenant.

The Japanese attack on Rabaul was a turning point in the war, and it was here that Headlam made his first combat sortie. On the night of 7-8 September, a B-25 bomber dropped a bomb on the airfield, killing one crew member and causing damage to the other two. The crew of the B-25 was rescued by a P-38 fighter and returned to base.

After the bombing, the New Britain airfield was closed to all aircraft except those of the Royal Flying Corps (RFC), which had been operating from the island for some time. This meant that RFC aircraft could not land at the airstrip, and the RFC was forced to take to the air in search of a landing site.

At this time, there were no aircraft capable of carrying a landing party of more than two men, so the RFC decided to fly a search and rescue mission to the island. They were joined by the RAF's 4th Flying Training Squadron, which had been based at Rabaul since the beginning of the war

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Headlam was given command of No. 2 Squadron at Laverton on 15 April 1941, and raised to wing commander on 1 July. Equipped with
reference_text: Lockheed Hudsons, the squadron mainly conducted maritime patrols in southern waters until 5 December, when four of its aircraft were ordered to Darwin, Northern Territory, in response to fears of Japanese aggression in the Pacific. On 7 December, this detachment established itself at Penfui, near Koepang in Dutch Timor, while No. 2 Squadron's eight remaining Hudsons were stationed at Darwin on standby. The following day, aware that Australia was now at war in the Pacific, one of the Penfui @-@ based Hudsons attacked the Japanese pearler Nanyo Maru, which was suspected of being a radio ship, and forced it aground. By 12 December, Headlam had transferred to Penfui as commanding officer of the base, as well as No. 2 Squadron.

Spitfire Mk.XIs, he was one of the most successful pilots in the RAF, winning a total of five DFCs (Defence Force Crosses) and the Distinguished Flying Cross with Oak Leaves and Cornflowers.

Headlam's career spanned three World Wars, and was the longest of any fighter pilot to have served in the RAF. He flew more than 1,000 sorties and racked up an impressive tally of 6,731 flying hours. In addition to his flying, he was a keen sportsman, taking part in boxing, rowing, golf and horse racing.

After the war, Headlam retired from the RAF to live in a caravan park in the West Country with his wife and two children. He died of a heart attack aged 88 in his caravan in the summer of 2001.

A memorial service was held at St Albans, Hertfordshire, on 7 July 2001. The headstone was unveiled by the Duke of Gloucester, Lord Mountbatten of Burma's Royal Horse Artillery, and his wife, Lady Diana Spencer-Bentin.

Sources: Wikipedia, Air Chief Marshal Sir Arthur Harris, Flight Lieutenant (Retd) David Cairns, RAF Museum, The Warbird Database, Wikipedia, The Flying Scotsman, The Battle of Britain Centenary Project, The Royal Air Force (RAF) Historical Research Branch, The National Archives

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> During January 1942, No. 2 Squadron's aircraft were dispersed at Penfui, Boeroe Island, and Darwin. The Penfui detachment
reference_text: attacked Japanese shipping taking part in the invasion of Celebes. Two Hudsons shot down or damaged three Japanese floatplanes that attacked them as they were bombing a transport ship on 11 January ; the next day both Hudsons were themselves shot down by Mitsubishi Zeros. Penfui was bombed by the Japanese for the first time on 26 January 1942, and attacked regularly thereafter, damaging some aircraft. The intact Hudsons were withdrawn to Darwin but Headlam and his staff remained at Penfui to enable the base to be used by aircraft during reconnaissance missions from Australia. On 18 February, Headlam was ordered to evacuate all his personnel except a small party to demolish the airfield with assistance from Sparrow Force. He returned to Darwin the following day, just as the city experienced its first raid by the Japanese. Four of No. 2 Squadron's Hudsons were destroyed in the attack ; the remainder were relocated to Daly Waters, where they continued to carry out reconnaissance and bombing missions against Japanese targets in Timor.

Headlam's career in the Army was distinguished by a high degree of success in all theatres of war. He was awarded the Distinguished Service Order (DSO) for gallantry in action on the Somme in 1916, and the Croix de Guerre with Palm for valour at Verdun in 1916. He was promoted to the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel in the Australian Army in 1918, and became Commandant of the 1st Battalion of the Royal Australian Artillery in 1919.

After the Armistice, Headlam was appointed Chief of the Defence Staff, and held this position until his retirement in 1942. He was a keen advocate of conscription, and his views were echoed by the War Cabinet in the decision to raise the age of conscription from 21 to 25 years.

In his memoirs, Headlam wrote: "There is no doubt that the war would have been won in the United Kingdom and the German occupation of France and Flanders had it not been for the efforts of the Australian Army. I am proud of the fact that we did not surrender, and that we fought to the last man and the last bullet."

The Lincolns conducted area bombing missions over communist @-@ held territory, as well as strikes against pinpoint targets. The Dakotas were tasked with courier flights, VIP transport and medical evacuations across South East Asia, and in Malaya with airlifting troops and cargo, dropping supplies to friendly forces and despatching propaganda leaflets. Headlam was slightly injured on 20 December, when a No. 38 Squadron Dakota he was co @-@ piloting on a supply drop crash @-@ landed at Kampong Aur in Pahang, following engine failure. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> On 19 February 1952, Headlam became senior air staff officer ( SASO ) at Eastern Area Command in Penrith, New South Wales. During his
reference_text: term as SASO, the RAAF began re @-@ equipping with English Electric Canberra jet bombers and CAC Sabre jet fighters. The Air Force also underwent a major organisational change, as it transitioned from a geographically based command @-@ and @-@ control system to one based on function, resulting in the establishment of Home ( operational ), Training, and Maintenance Commands. Eastern Area Command, considered a de facto operational headquarters owing to the preponderance of combat units under its control, was reorganised as Home Command in October 1953. Headlam was appointed an Officer of the Order of the British Empire ( OBE ) in the 1954 New Year Honours for his " exceptional ability and devotion to duty ". He was promoted to acting air commodore in May. His appointment as aide @-@ de @-@ camp to Queen Elizabeth II was announced on 7 October 1954.

Headlam had an interest in aviation from an early age, and in the summer of 1942 he joined the Royal Flying Corps (RFC) as a cadet. After the war he served in the RAAF, flying Spitfires and Gladiators, and was promoted to Squadron Leader in 1946. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross for his part in the Battle of Midway in 1942, and in 1947 he was appointed to the newly formed Air Defence Command (ADC) as a Senior Air Staff Officer (SASO).

In the early 1950s Headlam was involved in the development of the A-10 Warthog, a high-altitude attack aircraft that was the first to use supersonic (Mach 1.5) air-to-air refuelling.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Headlam was promoted to substantive air commodore on 1 January 1955. In November he was posted to RAAF Overseas Headquarters, London, and the following
reference_text: year undertook studies at the Imperial Defence College. Returning to Australia, he served as acting Air Member for Personnel at the Department of Air, Canberra, from 19 March to 21 October 1957, between the terms of Air Vice Marshals Fred Scherger and Allan Walters, and again from 24 August 1959 to 28 March 1960, between the terms of Walters and Air Vice Marshal Bill Hely. In this role Headlam occupied a seat on the Air Board, the service's controlling body that comprised its senior officers and was chaired by the Chief of the Air Staff. He was also one of two RAAF representatives to serve on a committee, chaired by businessman William John Allison, examining conditions of defence service ; the committee's recommendations led to a doubling of flight pay, among other improvements. Headlam's other positions at the Department of Air included Air Commodore Plans from October 1957 to January 1959, and Director General Plans and Policy from January to August 1959. The latter assignment put him in charge of the RAAF's Directorate of Intelligence. Headlam was appointed a Commander of the Order of the British Empire ( CBE ) in the 1958 Queen's Birthday Honours, gazetted on 3 June. In May 1960 he became acting Deputy Chief of the Air Staff.

Headlam's career was to take him to the front line of the Cold War, where he became a key figure in the development of the A-7 Corsair II and the F-104 Starfighter. He retired from the RAAF in 1972 and died in Perth in August 2012.

The aircraft in the photo are the Canberra-class frigates HMAS Stirling and HMAS Warramunga. They were decommissioned in the 1980s and have been in storage ever since. The Canberra-class frigates were the first of the class to be built, and their design was based on the design of the US battleship New Jersey. The class was named after the city of Canberra, which was the capital of Australia at the time of their construction.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> On 30 January 1961, Headlam joined the staff of Operational Command ( OPCOM ), the successor organisation to Home Command, responsible for the direction
reference_text: of RAAF operational units. He took over as Air Officer Commanding ( AOC ) OPCOM from Air Vice Marshal Val Hancock in April. Headlam was promoted to air vice marshal on 29 May. On 17 July 1962, he was posted to RAAF Base Butterworth, Malaya, and took up the appointment of AOC No. 224 Group RAF in Singapore one week later. He was succeeded as AOC OPCOM by Air Vice Marshal Alister Murdoch. As AOC No. 224 Group, Headlam had overall responsibility for regional air defence and offensive air operations during the Brunei Rebellion in December 1962, and the subsequent Konfrontasi between Indonesia and Malaysia that officially began the following month. Divorced from his first wife in 1956, he married widowed social worker Vernon Spence at the Sydney registry office on 20 January 1964. He handed over No. 224 Group to Air Vice Marshal Christopher Foxley @-@ Norris on 30 November.

of the war in Vietnam. He was a highly experienced officer with a long and distinguished career in the Royal Navy, serving as Commanding Officer of HMS Exeter from 1961 to 1963 and as Vice-Admiral in the Fleet Air Arm from 1963 to 1966.

Headlam's appointment was greeted with enthusiasm by the Admiralty, and in the weeks that followed he set about reorganising the organisation to ensure that it was capable of carrying out the tasks assigned to it. The first of these tasks was to establish a 'command and control' structure for the operations in South Vietnam, which was given the codename 'Vietnam Task Force'. This task force was divided into three components: (1) the Operations Group, consisting of the ships and aircraft of the Task Force; (2) the Air Group, consisting of the air and naval assets of the Task Force; and (3) the Intelligence Group, consisting of the intelligence assets of the Task Force. Each of these components was headed by a Commander-in-Chief (CINC), and each had its own staff, including a Chief of Staff, a Deputy Chief of Staff, and a Staff Officer. The CINCs were in turn headed by a Vice-Commander (VC) and a Senior Non-Commissioned Officer (SNO).
